Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandfather learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Story: I sat on the edge of my cot in the workers’ quarters, my phone buzzing in my hand. My daughter’s message was short but heavy: my grandson was struggling, and she needed me to talk to him. As a grandfather, I knew how much my presence mattered, especially now. But as I looked up, I saw the new notice pinned to the wall—an optional training session next week, the kind that could help me keep up with the younger guys and maybe even earn a little more. The foreman had made it clear that those who showed initiative would be remembered when overtime was handed out. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me. My family expected me to be there, to listen, to guide. My team expected me to show up, to learn, to pull my weight. I stared at the phone, torn between the voice of my blood and the call of my livelihood, my heart pounding with the fear of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
